subject: Re: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception?

messageBody:
This is using a hammer to kill a fly.

public void testExpectException() throws Exception {
try {
somethingThatThrowsIllegalArgumentException();
fail("No exception was thrown?!");
}
catch (IllegalArgumentException success) {
}
}

I don't see the value in the "exceptionCaught" flag, since it's easier to
place a fail() inside the try{...} at the point when the test has "gone too
far". Also, I don't see the value in catching the other exceptions and
failing -- let JUnit catch them and report them as errors. Within the
context of this test case, it would be an error: something else went wrong
while I was trying to test passing illegal arguments. Maybe the test is
bad, maybe the test environment is bad, maybe the code is just plain broken
somewhere else.

As a style point, I call the expected exception "success" to tell the
reader that the exception is expected.

Subject: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception?



Do you think the following observations are correct?

The Junit.org site has an FAQ section
(http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm) with the following
question: How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception?

The answer they give is not completely correct because it does not
account for the possiblility that another exception could be thrown.
It would be better to test that the intended exception is actually
thrown. For example:

// Test IllegalArgumentException is thrown when partnerID is null.
public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {

boolean exceptionCaught = false;

try {
boolean assignedStatus =
instancePartnerHierarchyWorker.isPartnerAssigned(null);
fail("IllegalArgumentException should be thrown.");

} catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {

// Test Succeeds.
exceptionCaught = true;

} catch (PartnerNotFoundException pnfe){

fail("PartnerNotFoundException should not be thrown.");

} catch (PersistenceException pe){

fail("PersistenceException should not be thrown.");
}

assertTrue(exceptionCaught);
}
